critique: This executive order establishes a Council for Rural Affairs to advise and assist the President on the development of non-metropolitan areas. It aims to expand employment opportunities and improve living conditions in rural America. The order emphasizes coordination between federal, state, and local governments, as well as the effective use of federal programs. There is no direct mention of immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The order seems to promote government intervention in the economy to support rural development. It also appears to centralize authority by creating a federal council to address rural issues. The ideological tilt is slightly liberal due to the focus on government intervention and social welfare.
